Row.Text: A chieftain and his matapule bathe in the vaikaukau, while their forebears rest nearby in royal tombs covered in hibiscus flower garlands. In the stillness of the water, in the constancy of the earth – mana.

The leaders of Tonga gather to welcome a new chieftain to their ranks. By drinking the kava, they seal the cosmic binding between themselves and the Tongan domain. All must go as the ancestors did, so that the ceremony is tapu, sacred.
First place the food within the circle.
First ensure all are in their proper seats.

Visitors to Ha'amonga 'a Maui stare wide-eyed at the configuration of massive stones, believing that only Maui himself could perform such a feat. Tongan fishers watch the tourists from their boats in bemusement.
Maui's burden is a boon to {1_STORY_CITY}.
Maui's burden is all of Tonga's boon.

Like others before him, the younger sibling of a noble lineage takes on the mantle of tehina, and all the charges that come with it – to herald the family's name on far-off shores, and keep its oceangoing traditions alive.
This name will be known far and wide.
A formation of unfamiliar birds in the sky heralds a twofold success: land is near, and the tehina's skills are good and true.
Meet a Distant Lands Civilization or Independent Power.
Traditions are strongest close to home.
Distant strangers will know Tonga's name.

The wanderlust that often possesses explorers drives them to discover the wonders of far-off places. But this Tongan discovers something far greater: that if you go far enough, you will find yourself at home once again.

When word returns with confirmation of {1_INDEPENDENT_CS}'s loyalty, many of the lesser nobles vie for hegemony over its lands. One chief, brash and young, promises to champion Tonga's dominance, while an elder guarantees an endless flow of tribute from the vassal.

In the aftermath of {1_Volcano}'s eruption, those who live in {2_STORY_CITY} wonder what it was that drew its settlers to seek the shelter of a volcano's shadow. The ruined homes and lost loved ones speak to folly; the richness of the surrounding lands, to wisdom.
+1 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture on Urban Districts Adjacent to Volcanoes.
+1 [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness on Urban Districts Adjacent to Volcanoes.

A family of three encounters a baby shark stuck in a tidepool, believing it to be a gift from the gods. After all, such creatures only come from Pulotu – paradise. But before they can catch it, the tide returns, and whisks the shark away.

As the dead are carted away, Tongan chieftains survey the aftermath of their campaign. {1_dispersed_independent} could have been a trading partner, or an ally against common enemies. Instead, all that remains here is a bloody patch of dirt.
The warriors will never be unburdened of this pain.
The survivors will never let Tonga forget.

The first yields from the harvest always goes to the chief's house. Dr. Rizal pauses to ask a farmer why they should give away their food in the time of most hunger, and the reply is simply: "kingly power enables all things".
Dr. Rizal must meet this chief.

When preparing tea, all must go according to plan: the table must be set, the tea at the right temperature, the sugar added before the milk. Countless {1_Civilization_Adj} citizens perform this ritual daily, and yet so few remember a time when the bowl they brought to their lips was filled with kava.
It is never too late to remember.
It is one memory among many.
